data.title: communicate
data.meta_description: COMMUNICATE meaning: 1. to share information with others by speaking, writing, moving your body, or using other signals…. Learn more.
data.text:
verb

us

Your browser doesn't support HTML5 audio

/kəˈmjuː.nə.keɪt/ uk

Your browser doesn't support HTML5 audio

/kəˈmjuː.nɪ.keɪt/

communicate verb (SHARE INFORMATION)

communicate with We can now communicate instantly with people on the other side of the world.

Unable to speak a word of the language, he communicated with (= using) his hands.

be communicated to Has the news been communicated to the staff yet?

As an actor he could communicate a whole range of emotions.

Thesaurus: synonyms, antonyms, and examples

tellMy friend told me you were looking for me.

let someone knowLet me know if you'd like to come.

giveCan you give the message to Jo?

communicateA 60-second TV commercial isn't always the best way to communicate a complex medical message.

informThe relatives of the injured have been informed of the accident.

notifyThe school has to notify parents if their children do not arrive at school.

See more results »

B2 [ I ]

to talk about your thoughts and feelings, and help other people to understand them:

communicate with I find I just can't communicate with her.

More examplesFewer examples

She went to see a clairvoyant who said he could communicate with her dead husband.

She is that rare animal, a brilliant scientist who can communicate her ideas to ordinary people.

Having knowledge is one thing but being able to communicate it to others is another kettle of fish.

His skill lies in his ability to communicate quite complex ideas very simply.

Coming up after the break, we have a man who claims he can communicate with fish.

SMART Vocabulary: related words and phrases

You can also find related words, phrases, and synonyms in the topics:

communicate verb (ROOMS)

[ I ] formal

If one room communicates with another, it connects with it through a door:

communicate with The bedroom communicates with both bathroom and hall.

communicating rooms

(Definition of communicate from the Cambridge Advanced Learner's Dictionary & Thesaurus © Cambridge University Press)

communicate | Intermediate English

communicate

verb [ I/T ]

us

Your browser doesn't support HTML5 audio

/kəˈmju·nɪˌkeɪt/

If two people communicate with each other, they are able to understand each other and have a satisfactory relationship:

[ I ] The play deals with the inability of people to communicate with the people they love.

(Definition of communicate from the Cambridge Academic Content Dictionary © Cambridge University Press)

Examples of communicate

communicate

On the job, the team functions as a single organism, communicating in a language secret to all but them.

Like others, he said, these criminals communicate within their own networks.

And you have to be able to communicate, to deliver your ideas to all the people.

In films, it has been communicated like it's on another planet, but it can be here and now.

The coverage is confusing, however, on whether the seven individuals were charged for failing to predict the earthquake or failing to properly communicate the risk.

If they were to find distant life forms, how would they communicate with them?

It also would have prohibited the office from employing staff to communicate with the public or the media.

We have to remember to communicate, connect and check-in with one another.

The employee is prohibited from knowingly communicating with students through a "personal" social-networking page.

They avoid being alone with kids or communicating with them in the evening.

We sort of communicated by picking up the guitar.

So, the question remains: as we adopt new and better ways to help people communicate, can we keep asking what is really being communicated?

He communicated that he was not to be trifled with.

All you can do to communicate is sing to each other.

These examples are from corpora and from sources on the web. Any opinions in the examples do not represent the opinion of the Cambridge Dictionary editors or of Cambridge University Press or its licensors.
